awd_titl_txt: Canonical Metrics, the Kahler-Ricci Flow, and Their Applica1ons
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research work focuses on a number of open problems and developing programs on canonical metrics in Kahler geometry, geometric flows, and complex Monge-Ampere equations in relation to geometry and physics. Recent progress and influx of new ideas have unraveled a deep, rich, and unifying structure among analysis, partial differential equations, complex Riemannian geometry, and algebraic geometry. The project also aims to bring in research and teaching innovation in mathematics from various disciplines and have an immediate beneficial effect on undergraduate and graduate students at Rutgers as well as in the regional mathematical community. The principal investigator will continue to organize and participate in the integrated research/education programs and activities that will promote the education level of the nation. Furthermore, the principal investigator plans to disseminate the exciting frontier research at the interface of analysis and geometry to a broad audience through lectures and survey papers.

These projects will investigate canonical metrics of Einstein type on Kahler varieties with mild singularities. In particular, the principal investigator will study the Riemannian geometric properties of such singular metrics and analytic moduli problems for Kahler-Einstein manifolds. The PI will continue to make progress in the analytic minimal model program with Ricci flow by studying both the finite time and long time formation of singularities of the Kahler-Ricci flow on algebraic varieties. Such singularity formation is reflected by canonical geometric surgeries equivalent to birational transformations and should be understood through global and local metric uniformization. The PI willy employ new theories and techniques from L^2-theory, nonlinear PDEs and Cheeger-Colding theory.  The research will develop new tools and give profound insights and understanding of topological, geometric and algebraic structures of complex spaces.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed research work focuses on a number of open problems and developing programs on canonical Kahler metrics, geometric flows and complex Monge-Ampere equations arising from geometry and physics.

The PI and his collaborators prove a general geometric compactness theorem for the space of Kahler-Einstein manifolds of negative constant scalar curvature in terms of dimensions and volume upper bounds. Any sequence in this space converges subsequentially to a finite union of complete Kahler-Einstein metric spaces without loss of volume. The convergence is smooth off a closed singular set of Hausdorff dimension no greater than 2n−4, and the limiting metric space is biholomorphic to the unique algebraic canonical model. The PI and his collaborators also show that the Weil-Petersson metric extends uniquely to a Kahler current with bounded and continuous local potentials on the algebraic compactification of the moduli space of canonically polarized manifolds.  These results are a high dimensional generalization of the well known compactness results for hyperbolic metrics on compact Riemann surfaces of fixed genus greater than one.

 The PI and his collaborators established a general diameter estimate for Kahler metrics, requiring only on an entropy bound and no lower bound on the Ricci curvature. The proof builds on recent PDE techniques for complex Monge-Ampere equations. This result settles a long standing problem for geometric boundedness of Kahler manifolds.  As a consequence, diameter bounds are obtained for long-time solutions of the Kahler-Ricci flow and finite-time solutions when the limiting class is big, as well as for special fibrations of Calabi-Yau manifolds.  A local noncollapsing result is also obtained by the PI and Guo. 

The J-equation proposed by Donaldson is a complex Hessian quotient equation on Kahler manifolds. The solvability of the J-equation is proved by PI and Weinkove to be equivalent to the existence of a subsolution. It is later conjectured by Lejmi-Szekelyhidi to be equivalent to a stability condition in terms of holomorphic intersection numbers as an analogue of the Nakai-Moishezon criterion in algebraic geometry. The PI establishes a Nakai-Moishezon type criterion for pairs of Kahler classes on analytic Kahler varieties. As a consequence, He proves Lejmi-Szekelyhidi's original conjecture for the J-equation and applies such a criterion to obtain a family of constant scalar curvature Kahler metrics on smooth minimal models. Such a nonlinear version of Nakai-Moishezon criterion can also be identified and generalized to algebraic and analytic slope conditions. The PI further identifies various slope conditions for a family of fully nonlinear complex PDEs.

The PI and his collaborators also proved various results such as metric ridigity of Kahler manifolds with Ricci lower bound and volume upper bound,  the existence and rigidty of complete Kahler-Einstein metrics near log canonical singlariteis and positivity of Weil-Petersson currents on algebraic canonical models. 

Problems in the proposal arise naturally from our attempts to understand nonlinear differential equations from geometry and physics. The PI continues to co-organize the complex analysis and geometry seminar at Rutgers and the Princeton-Rutgers joint PDE seminar. He initiated  the virtual learning seminar on complex geometry at Rutgers during the pandemic, aiming to build a complex geometry group at Rutgers. The learning seminar has attracted both regional researchers from New Brunswick and Newark campuses and international researchers from Europe and Asia. It has also served as a fruitful platform for exchange of ideas and collaborations. The PI participated and spoke at Rutgers undergraduate mathematics association (RUMA).
